Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ecological Knowledge and Predictions: Integrating Across Networks and National Observatories
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecology, the science of the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings, and its relevance to society are in a period of rapid change. As a society, we are becoming increasingly globalized, while at the same time facing a growing number of environmental challenges, many of which are international in scope and extent. At the same time, our ability to measure and monitor the world around us has changed dramatically, both through technology development, such as remote sensing, automated instrumentation and high-throughput DNA sequencing, and through the establishment of both top-down observatories and bottom-up research networks. Data is more open and interconnected and these changes are fundamentally shifting the questions we can address in ecological science.

The time is ripe to shift from conception to actively building international research collaborations that span international boundaries, ecological scale and observation systems. A workshop will be held in Arizona during February to bring together world leaders from the US, Canada, Australia, Mexico and South Africa in large scale ecological science. The workshop will investigate three major themes: 1) From data networks to knowledge networks, 2) ecological forecasting, and 3) training, education and outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported an international workshop on global ecology aimed at fostering collaborations that leverage national ecological observatories and international research networks. The workshop focused on what scientific advances can we achieve in the near term, given data that is available or coming online, and what new initiatives (e.g., training, education, tool development, cyberinfrastructure) would accelerate the scientific progress in, and societal relevance of, global ecology. The three major themes of the workshop were: 1) From Data Networks to Knowledge Networks; 2) Ecological Forecasting; and 3) Training, Education, and Outreach. The Ecological Knowledge and Prediction (EKP) workshop was held in Tucson, AZ on February 19-21, 2018.  A total of 37 people were in attendance, with representatives coming from the US, Canada, Mexico, South Africa, and Australia. The primary outcome of this meeting was increased dialog surrounding observatory and network science. Discussions around ecological forecasting at the workshop also contributed to the launch of the Ecological Forecasting Initiative (EFI) (https://ecoforecast.org), a grass-roots effort to build a community of practice among researchers interested in near-term ecological forecasting. The synthesis of ecological knowledge across networks and observatories, the use of that knowledge to make explicit, iterative predictions, and the need to train the next generation of scientists in network/observatory science, are all fundamentally interdisciplinary activities. Moving forward, the Ecological Forecasting Initiative is explicitly engaging with this broader community, including but not limited to: decision scientists, data scientists, statisticians, computer scientists, engineers, educators, and scientists in the physical environmental sciences (e.g. hydrology, atmospheric science, ocean science, geomorphology). Near-term ecological forecasts frequently aim to provide societally useful projections of ecological processes and ecosystem services. By fostering dialog in this area and the development of a community of practice, this meeting encouraged the emergence of best practices and spurred ideas for new ecological forecasts.
